EPC RATING: Current - 61D Potential – 82B COUNCIL TAX BAND: E TENURE: Freehold DIRECTIONAL NOTE: From the village green of Milford-on-Sea, proceed in a westerly direction along the High Street, joining Park Lane (B3058) towards the clifftop. After passing the Beach House Hotel on the left-hand side, take first right into De La Warr Road and first right into Rookcliff Way, following the road round to the right, where it will be seen on the left-hand side. Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village boasting a long shingle beach, lined with colourful beach huts and stunning unspoilt views across the Solent. The beach is a hive of activity in the summer with windsurfers, kite surfers, kayakers and paddle boarders, and swimmers also enjoying the sandbar at low tide. This traditional village is a secret haven of character and charm with its lively centre based around the Village Green offering a first-class range of shops, restaurants, pubs and cafes, as well as local amenities including a greengrocer, butchers, fishmongers, two general stores, a medical centre and a dental surgery. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the sea wall towards the popular market town of Lymington and the tranquil hamlet of Keyhaven as a perfect place to stop and enjoy views towards the Isle of Wight, Hurst Castle and the Needles. The walk from Keyhaven and Milford along Hurst Spit to the castle dating back to Tudor Times, is a must. To the west you can walk to Barton-on-Sea and enjoy the views across to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond. Milford-on-Sea has beautiful walks through sheltered woodland in the local Nature Reserves of Studland Common and the Pleasure Grounds as well as Sturt Pond. The New Forest National Park, only a short drive away, covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are only 3 miles away, and provide easy access by British Rail to the larger shopping centre of Southampton and the seaside resort of Bournemouth, both of which have airports for domestic and international flights. The New Forest village of Brockenhurst also provides a fast train service direct to London Waterloo.

Double window shopfront, ceiling light point Doorway to the rear of the shop leads to: Utility/Toilet Area: 6'7" x 5'10" (2m x 1.78m) overall Sink unit, base and eye level cupboard units, wc, wash hand basin TENURE: Freehold EPC RATING: Ground Floor Apartment 65D/First Floor Apartment 44E/Shop tbc COUNCIL TAX BAND: tbc DIRECTIONAL NOTE: From our office head towards the village green and No. 21 will be seen on the left-hand side, a short way after the pedestrian crossing MILFORD AND THE LOCAL AREA Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village with a comprehensive range of restaurants, pubs and cafes plus a good range of gift and local shops including a greengrocers, butchers and two general stores, plus a medical centre and dental surgery, based around the village green. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the Coastal Path towards Barton-on-Sea and Lymington, with stunning views towards the Isle of Wight and the Needles and westwards to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond or through sheltered woodland in the Milford-on-Sea Pleasure Grounds and Studland Common, both local Nature Reserves, or around Sturt Pond and along Hurst Shingle Bank to Hurst Castle which dates back to Tudor times. The New Forest National Park is a short drive away, The New Forest became a national park in 2005 and was once a royal hunting ground for William the Conqueror. It covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free in its ancient heaths and woodland. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. British Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for domestic and international flights. www.visitmilfordonsea.co.uk and www.milfordonsea.org are two excellent websites providing a wealth of local information and news about the village Stamp Duty charges and online calculator- www.gov.uk/stamp-duty-land-tax/residential-property-rates

Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village with a comprehensive range of restaurants, pubs and cafes plus a good range of gift and local shops including a greengrocers, butchers, fishmonger and two general stores, plus a medical centre and dental surgery, based around the village green. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the Coastal Path towards Barton-on-Sea and Lymington, with stunning views towards the Isle of Wight and the Needles and westwards to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond or through sheltered woodland in the Milford-on-Sea Pleasure Grounds and Studland Common, both local Nature Reserves, or around Sturt Pond and along Hurst Shingle Bank to Hurst Castle which dates back to Tudor times. The New Forest National Park is a short drive away, The New Forest became a national park in 2005 and was once a royal hunting ground for William the Conqueror. It covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free in its ancient heaths and woodland. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. British Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for domestic and international flights

Nestled in a peaceful cul-de-sac just moments from Lymington’s vibrant High Street, 3 Paddock Gardens offers an exceptional opportunity to own a beautifully presented home in one of the area’s most desirable positions. This elegant mock-Georgian end-terrace house combines classic styling with modern comfort, benefiting from immaculate interiors, generous living spaces and a private south-west facing courtyard garden. From the moment you enter, the home feels bright, welcoming and thoughtfully designed, making it ideal for anyone seeking a property that requires no further work—simply move in and enjoy. The ground floor flows effortlessly, beginning with a spacious hallway and convenient cloakroom before opening into the charming bay-fronted lounge. To the rear, the open-plan kitchen and dining room creates a sociable hub of the home, complete with built-in appliances including an induction hob, oven, dishwasher, fridge/freezer, washing machine and tumble drier. There is an area within the kitchen that is currently designed with a built in desk and storage which leads into the dining room area that over looks the pretty courtyard garden. Upstairs, there are two generous double bedrooms with fitted wardrobes and an additional single bedroom offer flexibility for families, guests or home working plus the modern fully tiled walk in shower with basin and storage underneath. The property is approached via a charming pathway framed by mature planting, with established beds and hedging creating an attractive and welcoming frontage. A side gate offers convenient access around the house. The rear garden is south-westerly facing and the garden is a delightful, low-maintenance haven, mainly paved to provide an ideal space for outdoor dining and relaxation. Well-stocked borders and mature shrubs add colour and interest throughout the year, while a further side area houses a timber shed with power and direct access to the garage with additional parking plus a gateway to the rear of the property. The garden enjoys an excellent degree of privacy and includes outside lighting and a useful outdoor tap. The location is one of the home’s greatest assets. Lymington’s boutique shops, cafés, restaurants and weekly market are all within easy walking distance, as are Waitrose, local schools and the railway station with quick links to Brockenhurst and onwards to London. The property also sits within easy reach of the New Forest National Park, providing endless opportunities for walking, cycling and exploring. With the popular Monkey House pub close by and excellent road access to both the town and the forest, this is a wonderfully convenient and highly sought-after location. Combining style, practicality and a prime location, 3 Paddock Gardens represents an outstanding home for those seeking the perfect balance of town convenience and coastal charm. Council Tax Band - D EPC Rating - C Maintenance Charge: Approx £115 per year for the private road to the garage and gutter cleaning.

An entrance door to the side of the property gives access to the entrance porch with further door opening to the entrance hall where there is a built-in coats cupboard and stairs rising to the first floor. Doors from the entrance hall give access to a cloakroom, the kitchen/breakfast room, sitting/dining room and the garage. The sitting/dining room is of an excellent size with patio doors opening to and overlooking the lovely rear garden. The kitchen was refitted a few years ago and has an excellent range of floor and wall hanging drawers and cupboards. Appliances include built-in oven, hob, extractor and there is a sink with window to the front aspect. To the first floor the landing gives access to the three double bedrooms. The main bedroom has built-in wardrobes and is set up for an en suite shower room. The third bedroom aslo has built-in wardrobes and there is a very large shower room servicing the bedrooms. Outside there is a good size driveway with lawn to side leading up to both the integral garage and the property. To the rear is a very good size, well stocked garden with patio immediately abutting the house and greenhouse and shed to the bottom of the garden. On reaching the junction with the A337 Lymington/Christchurch road, turn left and take the first left into Old Christchurch Road, second right into West Lane and West End Cottage will be seen on the right hand side. EVERTON AND THE SURROUNDING AREA Everton is a popular, pleasant village, enjoying a strong community spirit and with the benefit of a comprehensive post office/village store, church, social club, recreation ground with children's play area plus a village pub/restaurant. Everton is located midway between the towns of Lymington and New Milton which are only 3 miles away, and which provide easy access by British Rail to the larger shopping centre of Southampton and the seaside resort of Bournemouth, both of which have airports for domestic and international flights. The New Forest village of Brockenhurst also provides a fast train service direct to London Waterloo. In addition, Milford on Sea is approximately 1.5 miles from Everton and is a thriving coastal village boasting a long shingle beach, lined with colourful beach huts and stunning unspoilt views across the Solent. The beach is a hive of activity in the summer with windsurfers, kite surfers, kayakers and paddle boarders, and swimmers also enjoying the sandbar at low tide. This traditional village is a secret haven of character and charm with its lively centre based around the Village Green offering a first-class range of shops, restaurants, pubs and cafes, as well as local amenities including a greengrocer, butchers, fishmongers, two general stores, a medical centre and a dental surgery. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the sea wall towards the popular market town of Lymington and the tranquil hamlet of Keyhaven as a perfect place to stop and enjoy views towards the Isle of Wight, Hurst Castle and the Needles. The walk from Keyhaven and Milford along Hurst Spit to the castle dating back to Tudor Times, is a must. To the west you can walk to Barton-on-Sea and enjoy the views across to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond. Milford-on-Sea has beautiful walks through sheltered woodland in the local Nature Reserves of Studland Common and the Pleasure Grounds as well as Sturt Pond. The New Forest National Park, only a short drive away, covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. Stamp Duty charges and online calculator- www.gov.uk/stamp-duty-land-tax/residential-property-rates

After a very short distance and immediately after the pedestrian crossing, turn right into Barnes Lane and take the first right hand turning into Chaucer Drive where at the next junction turn right into Keats Avenue and then left into Wolsey Way. Continue along Wolsey Way until this road becomes Knowland Drive where after a short distance Deans Court will be seen on the right-hand side and the properties are numbered. MILFORD AND THE SURROUNDING AREA Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village with a comprehensive range of restaurants, pubs and cafes plus a good range of gift and local shops including a greengrocers, butchers and two general stores, plus a medical centre and dental surgery, based around the village green. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the Coastal Path towards Barton-on-Sea and Lymington, with stunning views towards the Isle of Wight and the Needles and westwards to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond or through sheltered woodland in the Milford-on-Sea Pleasure Grounds and Studland Common, both local Nature Reserves, or around Sturt Pond and along Hurst Shingle Bank to Hurst Castle which dates back to Tudor times. The New Forest National Park is a short drive away, The New Forest became a national park in 2005 and was once a royal hunting ground for William the Conqueror. It covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free in its ancient heaths and woodland. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. National Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for domestic and international flights. www.visitmilfordonsea.co.uk and www.milfordonsea.org are two excellent websites providing a wealth of local information and news about the village Stamp Duty charges and online calculator- www.gov.uk/stamp-duty-land-tax/residential-property-rates

At the soul of the home is an expansive, high-specification Shaker kitchen and breakfast room, featuring a professional range cooker and marble-effect surfaces. This social hub flows effortlessly into a bright living and dining area, further extended by a cozy snug that offers a perfect retreat for relaxation. Upstairs, three well-proportioned bedrooms are served by a remodelled family bathroom. Outside, the property enjoys a low-maintenance, west-facing rear garden which is ideal for afternoon sun, alongside ample off-road parking and an attached garage. You approach the property via a driveway which leads to a shingled area providing excellent off-road parking for multiple vehicles. A covered porch area leads through to the entrance hallway with a practical storage cupboard. The Snug/separate living area is a bright room featuring a large picture window that floods the space with natural light. The room centres around a decorative fireplace with a marble-effect hearth and ornate detailing. Light oak-effect flooring runs throughout. The Sitting/Dining Area is a dedicated entertaining space highlighted by an industrial-style geometric pendant light. It features triples aspects with double opening glazed doors which lead to the snug, two windows which overlook the side and French doors that open directly onto the level rear lawn. The impressive kitchen is an expansive, high-spec kitchen featuring sage green Shaker-style units and white marble-effect worktops with tiled flooring throughout. A professional stainless steel range cooker is the centre piece with fitted extractor over, set against white subway tile splashbacks. The room also features deep wicker storage baskets and a large window overlooking the garden. A recessed area provides space for an upright fridge freezer and there is further storage in the understairs cupboard. A door then leads through to the garage which is currently being used as a hobbies room with space and plumbing for a washing machine and dryer. A door then leads through to the rear garden. The home is served by a modern Vaillant boiler which is also located in the garage. To complete the downstairs accommodation is the Cloakroom: A practical ground-floor WC with a compact vanity sink and frosted window. The first-floor landing benefits from airing cupboard and hatch to loft storage space. The principal bedroom is a generous double room with a large window overlooking rear garden and benefits from fitted wardrobes. The second bedroom is another generous double room with large window overlooking front aspect it also benefits from fitted wardrobes. The third bedroom is perfect as a children’s room or a home office. The bedrooms are all served by the main family bathroom which is a luxuriously appointed suite featuring floor-to-ceiling sand-coloured tiling. It includes a bath with a gold-finished rainfall shower head and matching gold hardware, a modern pedestal sink, and a glass splash screen. Rear Garden: The easy to maintain, level garden is primarily laid to lawn and fully enclosed by timber fencing. It features a mature tree, a timber shed and a gravel area perfect for BBQing. EPC RATING: Current ~ TBC Potential ~ TBC COUNCIL TAX: D SERVICES: Mains water, electricity, gas and drainage. HEATING: Gas fired central heating. BROADBAND: Ultrafast up to 1000 mbps download (Ofcom)

Property management company fees are also included DIRECTIONAL NOTE: From the village green in the centre of Milford-on-Sea, proceed along the High Street in a westerly direction, joining Park Lane immediately after crossing the Danestream Bridge. On reaching the clifftop, continue until reaching the second car park on the left-hand side, turn right into Whitby Road and take the first left into Pless Road and enter Camden Hurst via the first entrance MILFORD AND THE LOCAL AREA Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village boasting a long shingle beach, lined with colourful beach huts and stunning unspoilt views across the Solent. The beach is a hive of activity in the summer with windsurfers, kite surfers, kayakers and paddle boarders, and swimmers also enjoying the sandbar at low tide. This traditional village is a secret haven of character and charm with its lively centre based around the Village Green offering a first-class range of shops, restaurants, pubs and cafes, as well as local amenities including a greengrocer, butchers, fishmongers, two general stores, a medical centre and a dental surgery. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the sea wall towards the popular market town of Lymington and the tranquil hamlet of Keyhaven as a perfect place to stop and enjoy views towards the Isle of Wight, Hurst Castle and the Needles. The walk from Keyhaven and Milford along Hurst Spit to the castle dating back to Tudor Times, is a must. To the west you can walk to Barton-on-Sea and enjoy the views across to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond. Milford-on-Sea has beautiful walks through sheltered woodland in the local Nature Reserves of Studland Common and the Pleasure Grounds as well as Sturt Pond. The New Forest National Park, only a short drive away, covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are only 3 miles away, and provide easy access by British Rail to the larger shopping centre of Southampton and the seaside resort of Bournemouth, both of which have airports for domestic and international flights. The New Forest village of Brockenhurst also provides a fast train service direct to London Waterloo.

EPC RATING: D COUNCIL TAX BAND: D DIRECTIONAL NOTE: From the village green in the centre of Milford-on-Sea, proceed out of the village in a northerly direction on the B3058 Lymington Road. On reaching the junction with the A337 Lymington/Christchurch Road, turn left and after a very short distance, turn right into Everton Road (signposted to Everton and Hordle), and take the second right into Frys Lane. Continue for a short distance and take the next right into Harts Way, then first right into Golden Crescent, left into Forest Way and the property will be seen on the left EVERTON Everton is a popular, pleasant village, enjoying a strong community spirit and with the benefit of a comprehensive post office/village store, church, social club, recreation ground with children's play area plus a village pub/restaurant. Everton is located midway between the towns of Lymington and New Milton which are only 3 miles away, and which provide easy access by British Rail to the larger shopping centre of Southampton and the seaside resort of Bournemouth, both of which have airports for domestic and international flights. The New Forest village of Brockenhurst also provides a fast train service direct to London Waterloo. In addition, Milford on Sea is approximately 1.5 miles from Everton and is a thriving coastal village boasting a long shingle beach, lined with colourful beach huts and stunning unspoilt views across the Solent. The beach is a hive of activity in the summer with windsurfers, kite surfers, kayakers and paddle boarders, and swimmers also enjoying the sandbar at low tide. This traditional village is a secret haven of character and charm with its lively centre based around the Village Green offering a first-class range of shops, restaurants, pubs and cafes, as well as local amenities including a greengrocer, butchers, fishmongers, two general stores, a medical centre and a dental surgery. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the sea wall towards the popular market town of Lymington and the tranquil hamlet of Keyhaven as a perfect place to stop and enjoy views towards the Isle of Wight, Hurst Castle and the Needles. The walk from Keyhaven and Milford along Hurst Spit to the castle dating back to Tudor Times, is a must. To the west you can walk to Barton-on-Sea and enjoy the views across to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond. Milford-on-Sea has beautiful walks through sheltered woodland in the local Nature Reserves of Studland Common and the Pleasure Grounds as well as Sturt Pond. The New Forest National Park, only a short drive away, covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding.

Accommodation The well planned accommodation provides spacious and comfortable living throughout. The front door leads into a good size entrance hall with stairs rising to the first floor with large understairs cupboard. The study sits just off the hallway and would make an ideal office or hobby room, adjacent to this is a cloakroom with wash basin and obscure window to one side. The generous sitting room enjoys an aspect over the front garden whilst the modern kitchen/dining room lies to the rear, fitted with a comprehensive range of floor standing and wall mounted cupboards and drawers with worktops incorporating a double sink unit with mixer tap, built in appliances include a five ring gas hob with extractor fan over, electric oven, microwave, fridge freezer and dishwasher. The dining room has ample space for table and chairs and enjoys a pleasant aspect over the rear garden. On the first floor a landing has a hatch giving access to the loft space and a storage cupboard. The principal bedroom lies to the front enjoying its own en-suite shower room, a modern suite comprising shower cubicle with mixer tap and tiled walls, wc and vanity wash hand basin. Bedrooms two and three have an aspect over the rear garden whilst the fourth bedroom overlooks the front. These bedrooms are serviced by a modern family bathroom with panelled bath having a mixer tap and hand shower, wash hand basin, wc, and heated towel rail. Outside the property is approached via secure electric double gates with an entry fob system, adjacent guest parking with a driveway leading round to the front and access to off street parking spaces. A pathway leads to the side to the front door and continues through a gateway into the rear garden, well enclosed by fencing with an area of terrace leading onto lawn with pathway leading to garden shed. The property is offered with no forward chain and must be viewed to fully appreciate this delightful location within the village of Hordle. Council Tax – E EPC Rating - C

A paved footpath leads to the Conservatory and the south facing rear garden, delightfully landscaped with areas of paved Sun Terrace, a central area of lawn, a feature Pergola, shrub and flower bed borders, two Timber Garden Stores, panel fenced boundaries and rear pedestrian gate GARAGE A conventional up and over door, light and power connected, personal door to the rear aspect and a further door adjacent to a store room set into the rear of the garage TENURE: Freehold EPC RATING: 62D COUNCIL TAX BAND: D DIRECTIONAL NOTE: From the village green in the centre of Milford-on-Sea, proceed in a northerly direction on the B3058 Lymington Road. On reaching the junction with the A337 Lymington/Christchurch road, turn left and after a very short distance, turn right into Everton Road. Take the second turning right into Frys Lane, and first right into Harts Way and number 6 can be found at the end of the close on the left hand side MILFORD AND THE SURROUNDING AREA Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village with a comprehensive range of restaurants, pubs and cafes plus a good range of gift and local shops including a greengrocers, butchers and two general stores, plus a medical centre and dental surgery, based around the village green. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the Coastal Path towards Barton-on-Sea and Lymington, with stunning views towards the Isle of Wight and the Needles and westwards to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond or through sheltered woodland in the Milford-on-Sea Pleasure Grounds and Studland Common, both local Nature Reserves, or around Sturt Pond and along Hurst Shingle Bank to Hurst Castle which dates back to Tudor times. The New Forest National Park is a short drive away, The New Forest became a national park in 2005 and was once a royal hunting ground for William the Conqueror. It covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free in its ancient heaths and woodland. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. National Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for domestic and international flights. www.visitmilfordonsea.co.uk and www.milfordonsea.org are two excellent websites providing a wealth of local information and news about the village Stamp Duty charges and online calculator- www.gov.uk/stamp-duty-land-tax/residential-property-rates

EPC RATING: 77C COUNCIL TAX BAND: D DIRECTIONS: From the village green in the centre of Milford-on-Sea proceed in a westerly direction along the High Street, joining Park Lane towards Barton-on-Sea (B3058). After passing the Beach House Hotel on the left and reaching the cliff top, take the third turning on the right into Whitby Road with Solent Pines being the first block on the right where the entrances will be seen and are numbered Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village boasting a long shingle beach, lined with colourful beach huts and stunning unspoilt views across the Solent. The beach is a hive of activity in the summer with windsurfers, kite surfers, kayakers and paddle boarders, and swimmers also enjoying the sandbar at low tide. This traditional village is a secret haven of character and charm with its lively centre based around the Village Green offering a first-class range of shops, restaurants, pubs and cafes, as well as local amenities including a greengrocer, butchers, fishmongers, two general stores, a medical centre and a dental surgery. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the sea wall towards the popular market town of Lymington and the tranquil hamlet of Keyhaven as a perfect place to stop and enjoy views towards the Isle of Wight, Hurst Castle and the Needles. The walk from Keyhaven and Milford along Hurst Spit to the castle dating back to Tudor Times, is a must. To the west you can walk to Barton-on-Sea and enjoy the views across to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond. Milford-on-Sea has beautiful walks through sheltered woodland in the local Nature Reserves of Studland Common and the Pleasure Grounds as well as Sturt Pond. The New Forest National Park, only a short drive away, covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are only 3 miles away, and provide easy access by British Rail to the larger shopping centre of Southampton and the seaside resort of Bournemouth, both of which have airports for domestic and international flights. The New Forest village of Brockenhurst also provides a fast train service direct to London Waterloo.

You approach the property via a wrought iron gate which leads into a stone pathway to an area of tiled patio. The glazed panelled front entrance door leads to tiled entrance hallway with opening through to a handy storage room which is currently being used as a home office. This benefits from a window overlooking the front aspect with views over the gardens and down Barrows Lane. A glazed wooden door then opens up into the living area with double glazed sash windows overlooking side gardens and large wood burning stove. An opening leads through to the reception room and both rooms benefit from double inset shelving/cupboard units with wood panelling and is one feature of many character features of the property. There is a further storage area and under stairs storage cupboard. A wooden glazed door leads to kitchen/family/dining room, the hub of the property and an impressive and well proportioned room. An abundance of light floods in from the many double aspect windows and large skylight above the kitchen. This area benefits from tiled flooring throughout and the kitchen boasts country charm, with wooden beam, wood worktops large tiled backsplash and there is currently space for an upright fridge freezer and range cooker. The wall mounted Worcester Bosch gas fired central heating boiler is also located in this room. An archway leads into the utility room which has tiled flooring which benefits from dual butler style sink and large drainer, space and plumbing for washing machine and pantry cupboard with double glazed window overlooking the gardens. The kitchen/family/dining room offers excellent views of the surrounding gardens. The bathroom is an excellent size with tiled checkerboard flooring and large obscure sash window overlooking the rear garden. The bathroom has an excellent sized separate shower unit and freestanding bath. Stairs from the second reception room lead to the first floor landing with window providing light and views across the garden. The principal bedroom benefits from solid wood floors and two sash windows overlooking fields and paddock land. The second bedroom has two built in storage cupboards and further fitted hanging rail with window overlooking rear aspect. There is currently a door which interlocks the two bedrooms. A drop down door gives access to further storage. The summerhouse boasts a decked veranda with outside power point. Inside there are two beautiful matching stained glass windows with two further sash windows overlooking the veranda and garden. The summerhouse is wonderfully versatile and can be used as a home office/gym or additional space to the Main house. It benefits from power points, insulation and separate fuse box. There is a further bike shed and store room. The gardens are deceptively spacious and to the rear right hand side you uncover a quaint patio area perfect for alfresco dining/entertaining. The garden is slightly raised above barrows lane giving elevated views across paddocks and fields opposite. The garden is mainly laid to lawn with interspersed shrubs and flowers which is all enclosed by wood panel fencing. The property benefits from off road parking with a driveway providing space for three vehicles. EPC RATING: Current ~ D57 Potential ~ C73 COUNCIL TAX BAND: D SERVICES: Mains water, electricity and gas. Private drainage. HEATING: Gas fired central heating. BROADBAND: Fibre to Cabinet Broadband up to 76mbps download (Ofcom). CONSTRUCTION: We have been advised that the property is of concrete construction.

The towns of Lymington and New Milton are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. National Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for domestic and international flights. www.visitmilfordonsea.co.uk and www.milfordonsea.org are two excellent websites providing a wealth of local information and news about the village Stamp Duty charges and online calculator- www.gov.uk/stamp-duty-land-tax/residential-property-rates

The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the Coastal Path towards Barton-on-Sea and Lymington, with stunning views towards the Isle of Wight and the Needles and westwards to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond or through sheltered woodland in the Milford-on-Sea Pleasure Grounds and Studland Common, both local Nature Reserves, or around Sturt Pond and along Hurst Shingle Bank to Hurst Castle which dates back to Tudor times. The New Forest National Park is a short drive away. The New Forest became a national park in 2005 and was once a royal hunting ground for William the Conqueror. It covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free in its ancient heaths and woodland. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. National Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for domestic and international flights. www.visitmilfordonsea.co.uk and www.milfordonsea.org are two excellent websites providing a wealth of local information and news about the village Stamp Duty charges and online calculator- www.gov.uk/stamp-duty-land-tax/residential-property-rates

After a short distance the road becomes Keyhaven Road and New Lane is the third turning on the right. Solent Grange is the second turning on the right-hand side, when you enter Solent Grange bare right, follow the signage, and No 50 will be on the left hand side SOLENT GRANGE is a development of residential luxury bungalows located on the Milford coastline, providing accommodation specifically for the over 45's and benefiting from an on-site manager and ground staff. Solent Grange enjoys a superb location within the thriving coastal village of Milford-on-Sea - with easy level access to the village green which offers a fine selection of shops, hostelries, award winning restaurants, a medical centre, dental surgery and a vibrant village community centre with the village green hosting a wide selection of events throughout the year The area is popular with walkers, gentle strolls can be enjoyed along the Solent Coastal Path with its protected marshlands and stunning coastal views or through the sheltered Milford Pleasure Grounds Nature Reserve. The wonderful expanse of the New Forest National Park is just a short drive away, and the characterful Regency town of Lymington with its ferry crossings to the Isle of Wight, and the comprehensive shopping towns of New Milton which are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. British Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for internal and external flights Available with direct access from Solent Grange is Sturt Pond and Keyhaven Nature Reserve, with a well-maintained path leading to the Shinglebank and access to Hurst Castle. Hurst Castle is an English Heritage site and is situated at the seaward end of the shingle bank that extends 1.5 miles from Milford-On-Sea. The end of the spit is only three-quarters of a mile from the Isle of Wight and the outlook from the top of the Tudor castle with its Napoleonic additions are spectacular, providing panoramic views of the Solent, the Isle of Wight and the Needles, with westerly vistas towards Christchurch Bay and the Purbeck Hills in Dorset.

You access the property via a recently fitted brick paviour driveway which provides good off road parking. This leads to a large covered porch with two brick pillars and EV car charging point. A composite glazed front door with obscure matching side panel leads into the entrance hallway which has contemporary tiled floor throughout. A door then leads through into the kitchen/breakfast room which has been recently modernised by the current vendors. The contemporary tiled floor runs throughout with an excellent range of quartz worktops with tiled splashback and plenty of soft close cupboards and drawers above and below. Integrated appliances include fridge/freezer, dishwasher, four ring halogen hob with extractor over, Neff eye level oven and further microwave grill below. There is also a pantry cupboard and wall mounted cupboard housing the Worcester gas fired central heating boiler. Double windows and a patio door overlook the rear garden. The contemporary tiled floor continues into the utility room/w.c which provides plenty of space for cloaks and shoes. There is space and plumbing for a washing machine and further cupboard space with tiled splashback, attractive wood panelling and extractor. The sitting/dining room is a good sized room with front to back aspects and double opening patio doors leading to the rear garden. There is a Clearview wood burning stove creating a wonderful focal point. Stairs from the entrance hallway lead to the first floor landing with window overlooking rear gardens, hatch to loft space which is fully boarded. A door leads to a separate w.c with obscure window overlooking rear gardens. The principal bedroom is a good sized double bedroom and has two newly fitted double wardrobes and further wardrobe cupboard providing excellent storage space with large windows which overlook the front aspect. Bedroom two is another good-sized double room and provides an airing cupboard with plenty of slatted shelving and hot water cylinder. Large windows also overlook the front aspect. Bedroom three is a single bedroom with windows overlooking the rear garden and it benefits from a large fitted wardrobe. The main bathrooms services all three bedrooms and has fully tiled walls with white panelled bath and triton shower attachment over. There is an obscure window overlooking the rear garden, shaving point and extractor fan. The rear garden gives plenty of outside space and boasts westerly aspects and can be also be accessed via a pathway behind the neighbouring property. There is a good sized area of patio, raised beds and wooden storage shed. Property note: In the last five years the property has benefitted from all new double glazing throughout, guttering, and new roof. We also understand from the vendors that the property benefits from Commoners Rights of Pasture subject to the owner being able to comply with the requirements of back up grazing. EPC RATING: Current ~ TBC Potential ~ TBC COUNCIL TAX BAND: C SERVICES: Mains water, gas, electricity and drainage. HEATING: Gas fired central heating. BROADBAND: Ultrafast up to 1000 mbps download (Ofcom).

MILFORD AND THE SURROUNDING AREA Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village with a comprehensive range of restaurants, pubs and cafes plus a good range of gift and local shops including a greengrocers, butchers and two general stores, plus a medical centre and dental surgery, based around the village green. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the Coastal Path towards Barton-on-Sea and Lymington, with stunning views towards the Isle of Wight and the Needles and westwards to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond or through sheltered woodland in the Milford-on-Sea Pleasure Grounds and Studland Common, both local Nature Reserves, or around Sturt Pond and along Hurst Shingle Bank to Hurst Castle which dates back to Tudor times. The New Forest National Park is a short drive away, The New Forest became a national park in 2005 and was once a royal hunting ground for William the Conqueror. It covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free in its ancient heaths and woodland. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. National Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for domestic and international flights. www.visitmilfordonsea.co.uk and www.milfordonsea.org are two excellent websites providing a wealth of local information and news about the village Stamp Duty charges and online calculator- www.gov.uk/stamp-duty-land-tax/residential-property-rates

You access the property via a secure front door with telecom system which leads to a communal entrance hallway shared with just one other apartment. From there, stairs with a fitted stairlift (can be removed as required) lead to the first floor landing and personal front door to the apartment. This leads into the spacious entrance hallway with entry phone system, which includes a coats cupboard, a boiler cupboard (gas fired central heating Glow worm boiler) and an airing cupboard with pressurised hot water cylinder. All providing excellent storage. There is also a window overlooking the rear aspect and a hatch to the extensive loft storage space with fitted drop down ladder. Double opening wooden glazed doors lead into the impressive hub of the property which is the spacious kitchen/living/dining room. This space is beautifully filled with light from the large dual aspect windows overlooking front and side aspects. The living area boasts a feature fireplace with electric fire. The kitchen area has tiled flooring and a central island providing storage and a breakfast bar. There is a good range of roll edge worktops with tiled splashback and integrated appliances including eye level Bosch oven and grill, five ring gas hob with central ‘wok burner’, extractor fan over, microwave cooker, dishwasher and washing machine. The principal bedroom is a superb double room with two fitted wardrobes with sliding doors providing plenty of storage. Two windows overlook the side aspect and a door leads to the en suite shower room with good sized corner shower cubicle, extractor fan and fully tiled walls. Bedroom two is a good sized double bedroom with windows overlooking the front aspect and is serviced by the main bathroom which comprises a white bath tub with shower attachment, extractor fan and vanity units. The property benefits from an allocated parking space, secure entrance system and bin store. EPC RATING: Current ~ C79 Potential ~ C79 COUNCIL TAX BAND: C SERVICES: Mains water, electricity, gas and drainage. HEATING: Gas fired central heating. BROADBAND: Up to 1000 mbps download (Ofcom) LEASE: 125 years from 1 November 2006. SERVICE CHARGE: £1518 pa GROUND RENT: Nil

After a short distance the road becomes Keyhaven Road, take second left into Carrington Lane and first right into Champion Close, where the property will be seen on the right and is numbered MILFORD AND THE SURROUNDING AREA Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village with a comprehensive range of restaurants, pubs and cafes plus a good range of gift and local shops including a greengrocers, butchers and two general stores, plus a medical centre and dental surgery, based around the village green. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the Coastal Path towards Barton-on-Sea and Lymington, with stunning views towards the Isle of Wight and the Needles and westwards to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond or through sheltered woodland in the Milford-on-Sea Pleasure Grounds and Studland Common, both local Nature Reserves, or around Sturt Pond and along Hurst Shingle Bank to Hurst Castle which dates back to Tudor times. The New Forest National Park is a short drive away, The New Forest became a national park in 2005 and was once a royal hunting ground for William the Conqueror. It covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free in its ancient heaths and woodland. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. National Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for domestic and international flights. www.visitmilfordonsea.co.uk and www.milfordonsea.org are two excellent websites providing a wealth of local information and news about the village Stamp Duty charges and online calculator- www.gov.uk/stamp-duty-land-tax/residential-property-rates

The property offers well proportioned accommodation facing in an easterly direction to the front and westerly to the rear opening onto the patio garden. A private entrance door with covered porch to the side of the property gives access to the hallway which has two large built-in storage cupboards and gives access to all rooms. There is a good size living room/kitchen. The kitchen area is fitted with a modern range of wall and base units with co-ordinating worksurfaces, integrated appliances including oven, ceramic hob, fridge/freezer and washing machine. The gas central heating boiler is in one of the wall cupboards. In the living area double glazed French doors open to the patio garden. The two bedrooms are of a good size. The bathroom comprises a panelled bath with shower attachment over, wash hand basin and low level w.c. Outside is the westerly facing patio garden enclosed by fencing and giving access to the allotted parking space to the rear which is access from Brookley Road. In addition there is a shared storage cupboard, bike and bin store. TENURE: Leasehold TERM: 99 years from 2007 (We understand that a lease extension is currently being arranged to extend the lease to 189 years.) SERVICE CHARGE: £1,152 pa GROUND RENT: Peppercorn Pets by prior agreement only. No holiday or short term rentals but we understand standard assured tenancy is permitted. EPC RATING: Current ~ C76 Potential ~ C77 COUNCIL TAX BAND: C SERVICES: Mains water, electricity, gas and drainage. HEATING: Gas fired central heating. BROADBAND: Ultrafast up to 1000 mbps download (Ofcom).

EPC RATING: 67D COUNCIL TAX BAND: C TENURE: Freehold DIRECTIONAL NOTE: From our office head towards the village green and The Old Bakery will be seen on the right Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village boasting a long shingle beach, lined with colourful beach huts and stunning unspoilt views across the Solent. The beach is a hive of activity in the summer with windsurfers, kite surfers, kayakers and paddle boarders, and swimmers also enjoying the sandbar at low tide. This traditional village is a secret haven of character and charm with its lively centre based around the Village Green offering a first-class range of shops, restaurants, pubs and cafes, as well as local amenities including a greengrocer, butchers, fishmongers, two general stores, a medical centre and a dental surgery. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the sea wall towards the popular market town of Lymington and the tranquil hamlet of Keyhaven as a perfect place to stop and enjoy views towards the Isle of Wight, Hurst Castle and the Needles. The walk from Keyhaven and Milford along Hurst Spit to the castle dating back to Tudor Times, is a must. To the west you can walk to Barton-on-Sea and enjoy the views across to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond. Milford-on-Sea has beautiful walks through sheltered woodland in the local Nature Reserves of Studland Common and the Pleasure Grounds as well as Sturt Pond. The New Forest National Park, only a short drive away, covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are only 3 miles away, and provide easy access by British Rail to the larger shopping centre of Southampton and the seaside resort of Bournemouth, both of which have airports for domestic and international flights. The New Forest village of Brockenhurst also provides a fast train service direct to London Waterloo.

After passing the Beach House Hotel on the clifftop, take first right into De La Warr Road and first left into Victoria Road, where the entrance to Osborne Court will be seen on the left hand side Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village boasting a long shingle beach, lined with colourful beach huts and stunning unspoilt views across the Solent. The beach is a hive of activity in the summer with windsurfers, kite surfers, kayakers and paddle boarders, and swimmers also enjoying the sandbar at low tide. This traditional village is a secret haven of character and charm with its lively centre based around the Village Green offering a first-class range of shops, restaurants, pubs and cafes, as well as local amenities including a greengrocer, butchers, fishmongers, two general stores, a medical centre and a dental surgery. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the sea wall towards the popular market town of Lymington and the tranquil hamlet of Keyhaven as a perfect place to stop and enjoy views towards the Isle of Wight, Hurst Castle and the Needles. The walk from Keyhaven and Milford along Hurst Spit to the castle dating back to Tudor Times, is a must. To the west you can walk to Barton-on-Sea and enjoy the views across to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond. Milford-on-Sea has beautiful walks through sheltered woodland in the local Nature Reserves of Studland Common and the Pleasure Grounds as well as Sturt Pond. The New Forest National Park, only a short drive away, covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are only 3 miles away, and provide easy access by British Rail to the larger shopping centre of Southampton and the seaside resort of Bournemouth, both of which have airports for domestic and international flights. The New Forest village of Brockenhurst also provides a fast train service direct to London Waterloo.

Stairs leads up to the front door into the entrance hallway. The fully tiled main bathroom features contemporary fittings including a full-length bath and sleek vanity units. A spacious kitchen offers an array of worktops with large window overlooking side aspect. Integrated appliances include four ring electric hob and oven with extractor over. A tiled floor is laid throughout. Bedroom one is located on the first floor a good-sized double room. The standout feature is the exceptionally large living room, boasting a beautiful bay of windows overlooking the high street with a character fireplace. This bright and spacious room provides an impressive setting for both everyday living and entertaining. Stairs lead to the second floor teach with two bedrooms. The layout provides flexibility for families, professionals, or those needing dedicated office space. Positioned among Brockenhurst’s well-regarded independent shops, cafés, butchers, and eateries, the property places village life right on your doorstep. Brockenhurst Station, providing fast mainline links to London Waterloo, is within easy walking distance. The surrounding New Forest National Park offers miles of open heathland, woodland trails, and outdoor activities. OUTSIDE COMMUNAL GROUNDS – attractive and well-maintained southerly aspect communal grounds PARKING - allocated underground parking space, additional parking on site (not allocated) SWIMMING POOL - outdoor and heated from May to October, surrounded by a wide enclosed terrace with adjacent GAMES/FUNCTION/CLUB ROOM HARD TENNIS COURT ALL-WEATHER BOWLING GREEN AND PETANQUE PITCH TENURE: Share of Freehold EPC RATING: 74C COUNCIL TAX BAND: D MAINTENANCE: Maintenance of the building and grounds is administered by Owens & Porter. The charge is £1866.50 per half year and includes maintenance of the communal areas, swimming pool, tennis court, bowling green, pétanque pitch, games/function/clubroom and the services of a site supervisor providing janitorial duties, buildings insurance, water and sewage charges, cleaning of communal areas, monthly external window cleaning, gardening and grass cutting, maintenance of lifts and security system, and a contribution to a sinking fund. Property management company fees are also included DIRECTIONAL NOTE: From the village green in the centre of Milford-on-Sea, proceed along the High Street in a westerly direction, joining Park Lane immediately after crossing the Danestream Bridge. On reaching the clifftop, continue until reaching the second car park on the left-hand side, turn right into Whitby Road and take the first left into Pless Road and enter Camden Hurst via the first entrance MILFORD AND THE SURROUNDING AREA Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village with a comprehensive range of restaurants, pubs and cafes plus a good range of gift and local shops including a greengrocers, butchers and two general stores, plus a medical centre and dental surgery, based around the village green. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the Coastal Path towards Barton-on-Sea and Lymington, with stunning views towards the Isle of Wight and the Needles and westwards to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond or through sheltered woodland in the Milford-on-Sea Pleasure Grounds and Studland Common, both local Nature Reserves, or around Sturt Pond and along Hurst Shingle Bank to Hurst Castle which dates back to Tudor times. The New Forest National Park is a short drive away, The New Forest became a national park in 2005 and was once a royal hunting ground for William the Conqueror. It covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free in its ancient heaths and woodland. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. British Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for domestic and international flights. www.visitmilfordonsea.co.uk and www.milfordonsea.org are two excellent websites providing a wealth of local information and news about the village Stamp Duty charges and online calculator- www.gov.uk/stamp-duty-land-tax/residential-property-rates

Keyhaven and Hurst Castle). After a short distance the road becomes Keyhaven Road and New Lane is the third turning on the right. Solent Grange is the second turning on the right-hand side, when you enter Solent Grange bare right, follow the signage, and No 26 will be on the right hand side COUNCIL TAX BAND: A PITCH FEE: £233.65 per month TENURE: In Perpetuity SOLENT GRANGE is a development of residential luxury bungalows located on the Milford coastline, providing accommodation specifically for the over 45's and benefiting from an on-site manager and ground staff. Solent Grange enjoys a superb location within the thriving coastal village of Milford-on-Sea - with easy level access to the village green which offers a fine selection of shops, hostelries, award winning restaurants, a medical centre, dental surgery and a vibrant village community centre with the village green hosting a wide selection of events throughout the year The area is popular with walkers, gentle strolls can be enjoyed along the Solent Coastal Path with its protected marshlands and stunning coastal views or through the sheltered Milford Pleasure Grounds Nature Reserve. The wonderful expanse of the New Forest National Park is just a short drive away, and the characterful Regency town of Lymington with its ferry crossings to the Isle of Wight, and the comprehensive shopping towns of New Milton which are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. British Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for internal and external flights Available with direct access from Solent Grange is Sturt Pond and Keyhaven Nature Reserve, with a well-maintained path leading to the shingle bank and access to Hurst Castle. Hurst Castle is an English Heritage site and is situated at the seaward end of the shingle bank that extends 1.5 miles from Milford-On-Sea. The end of the spit is only three-quarters of a mile from the Isle of Wight and the outlook from the top of the Tudor castle with its Napoleonic additions are spectacular, providing panoramic views of the Solent, the Isle of Wight and the Needles, with westerly vistas towards Christchurch Bay and the Purbeck Hills in Dorset.

It covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free in its ancient heaths and woodland. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. National Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for domestic and international flights. www.visitmilfordonsea.co.uk and www.milfordonsea.org are two excellent websites providing a wealth of local information and news about the village Stamp Duty charges and online calculator- www.gov.uk/stamp-duty-land-tax/residential-property-rates

There is a Visitors Suite with overnight facilities, a Residents Lounge with an adjoining kitchen and access to the grounds and a Laundry Room with washing machines and tumble dryers TENURE: Leasehold - 125 years from 1994 MAINTENANCE: £2,641.52 per annum (payable in two instalments) to include buildings insurance, water and sewerage charges, window cleaning (every 4 - 6 weeks), upkeep of grounds, decor and maintenance of exterior and communal areas, lift maintenance and a contingency fund GROUND RENT: £257.13 per half year EPC RATING: Current - 77C Potential – 82B COUNCIL TAX BAND: C DIRECTIONAL NOTE: From the centre of Milford-on-Sea, at the village green, turn right into Sea Road, where the entrance to Danestream Court is situated a short way along on the right hand side and is named Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village boasting a long shingle beach, lined with colourful beach huts and stunning unspoilt views across the Solent. The beach is a hive of activity in the summer with windsurfers, kite surfers, kayakers and paddle boarders, and swimmers also enjoying the sandbar at low tide. This traditional village is a secret haven of character and charm with its lively centre based around the Village Green offering a first class range of shops, restaurants, pubs and cafes, as well as local amenities including a greengrocers, butchers, fishmongers, two general stores, a medical centre and a dental surgery. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the sea wall towards the popular market town of Lymington and the tranquil hamlet of Keyhaven as a perfect place to stop and enjoy views towards the Isle of Wight, Hurst Castle and the Needles. The walk from Keyhaven and Milford along Hurst Spit to the castle dating back to Tudor Times, is a must. To the west you can walk to Barton-on-Sea and enjoy the views across to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond. Milford-on-Sea has beautiful walks through sheltered woodland in the local Nature Reserves of Studland Common and the Pleasure Grounds as well as Sturt Pond. The New Forest National Park, only a short drive away, covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are only 3 miles away, and provide easy access by British Rail to the larger shopping centre of Southampton and the seaside resort of Bournemouth, both of which have airports for domestic and international flights. The New Forest village of Brockenhurst also provides a fast train service direct to London Waterloo.

displayAddress: Barton On Sea, New Milton, Hampshire

detailedDescription: Beach Hut 17 - 10’3" x 8' (3.14m x 2.44m) A pretty well maintained beach hut with double opening timber doors opening directly on to a good sized elevated decked terrace measuring 11’10” x 8’9” (3.38m x 2.71m) with the panoramic 180 degree views of the Isle of Wight, Needles to the east through to Christchurch Bay and Bournemouth to the west. Please see the NFDC website for details regarding the Annual Beach Hut Fees & Charges Directions: From Milford-on-Sea village centre, proceed out of the village in a westerly direction along the High Street, joining Park Lane (B3058), which on reaching the clifftop, becomes Cliff Road. Take the second left into the car park (with the kiosk) then walking away from the village and take the last set of steps. At the first tier turn right and No.17 is immediately on your left hand side located close to the tap and shower

BEACH HUT 59 7'6" x 7'3" (2.29m x 2.2m) Double doored entrance onto a good sized deck, two tiers up from the beach giving a spectacular elevated beach, Solent approach, Isle of White, Needles outlook extending to Christchurch, Bournemouth Bay and the Purbecks in the west DIRECTIONAL NOTE: From the kiosk car park head in a westerly direction (away from Milford Village) take the set of steps after the kiosk steps to the first level, turn right and after a very short distance 59 will be found MILFORD AND THE SURROUNDING AREA Milford on Sea is a thriving coastal village with a comprehensive range of restaurants, pubs and cafes plus a good range of gift and local shops including a greengrocers, butchers and two general stores, plus a medical centre and dental surgery, based around the village green. The Village Green is home to several events during the year, including an Arts & Music Festival, May Fair, Dog Show and Christmas Carol Service, with the Community Centre and the four village churches running busy programmes throughout the year. Walks can be enjoyed along the Coastal Path towards Barton-on-Sea and Lymington, with stunning views towards the Isle of Wight and the Needles and westwards to Christchurch Bay, Hengistbury Head and the Purbeck Hills beyond or through sheltered woodland in the Milford-on-Sea Pleasure Grounds and Studland Common, both local Nature Reserves, or around Sturt Pond and along Hurst Shingle Bank to Hurst Castle which dates back to Tudor times. The New Forest National Park is a short drive away, The New Forest became a national park in 2005 and was once a royal hunting ground for William the Conqueror. It covers an area of 566 square kilometres and is made up of vast tracts of unspoilt woodland, heathland and river valleys where deer, ponies and cattle continue to roam free in its ancient heaths and woodland. Clear rivers and shady groves provide tranquillity and a car-free haven for walking, cycling and horse riding. The towns of Lymington and New Milton are both approximately 3 miles away, with the larger shopping centres of Bournemouth and Southampton approximately equi-distant, about 18 miles away. National Rail Stations at New Milton and Brockenhurst provide a fast service to London Waterloo, with Bournemouth and Southampton airports easily accessed for domestic and international flights. www.visitmilfordonsea.co.uk and www.milfordonsea.org are two excellent websites providing a wealth of local information and news about the village

displayAddress: Princess Royal Close, Lymington, Hampshire, SO41 9NY
detailedDescription: Very well presented detached family home in a popular ;location close to Lymington town centre. Available now and offered unfurnished. Hayward Fox are pleased to offer for let: * Detached family home * Three bedrooms * Master bedroom with ensuite * Living room * Kitchen/ breakfast room * Driveway * Integral garage * Private rear garden * EPC band C * Council Tax E * Affordability: Prospective tenants will need to earn a combined Â£60,000pa and have clear credit history. Lymington is a lively sailing town at the mouth of the Lymington River enhanced by its marinas, yacht haven and sailing clubs. The Isle of Wight ferry operates regularly to Yarmouth. The lanes and streets around the Quay side retain the flavour of an old harbour town with Georgian and Victorian cottages, houses and unique shops. The bustling High Street supports an excellent variety of community facilities with a Saturday street market. Lymington is an ideal location for water sports enthusiasts with superb walks along the Foreshore with a wide range of recreational facilities being available throughout the New Forest National Park which surrounds the town. Lymington also has a nine hole golf course in an enviable position with views extending to the Isle of Wight, tennis club, bowls, cricket, rugby and football clubs, a wide range of schools and a recreation centre. Lymington is served by a good communication with road and rail links with the town railway station providing twice hourly access to Brockenhurst, a mainline station to London Waterloo. The international airports of Bournemouth and Southampton are both within 45 minute's' drive.
